{{short description|December 2007 – June 2009 banking emergency in the USA}} {{Subprime mortgage crisis sidebar}} The United States '''subprime mortgage crisis''' was a nationwide [[financial crisis]], occurred between 2007 and 2010, that contributed to the U.S. [[Financial crisis of 2007–2008|recession of December 2007 – June 2009]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Duca |first1=John V. (Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas) |title=Subprime Mortgage Crisis |url=https://www.federalreservehistory.org/essays/subprime_mortgage_crisis |accessdate=May 15, 2017 |agency=[[Federal Reserve]] |publisher=Federal Reserve History |date=2014 |quote=The expansion of mortgages to high-risk borrowers, coupled with rising house prices, contributed to a period of turmoil in financial markets that lasted from 2007 to 2010.}}</ref><ref>[https://www.nber.org/cycles/ US Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310081706/http://www.nber.org/cycles/ |date=March 10, 2009 }}, NBER, accessed August 9, 2012.</ref> It was triggered by a large decline in home prices after the collapse of a [[United States housing bubble|housing bubble]], leading to mortgage delinquencies, foreclosures, and the devaluation of [[Mortgage-backed security|housing-related securities]]. Declines in residential investment preceded the recession and were followed by reductions in household spending and then business investment. Spending reductions were more significant in areas with a combination of high household debt and larger housing price declines.<ref name="Mian and Sufi2014">{{cite book |last=Mian, Atif and |first=Sufi, Amir |year=2014 |title=House of Debt |publisher=University of Chicago |isbn=978-0-226-08194-6|title-link=House of Debt }}</ref>
The housing bubble preceding the crisis was financed with [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]] (MBSes) and [[collateralized debt obligation]]s (CDOs), which initially offered higher interest rates (i.e. better returns) than government securities, along with attractive risk ratings from [[Credit rating agency|rating agencies]]. While elements of the crisis first became more visible during 2007, several major financial institutions collapsed in September 2008, with significant disruption in the flow of credit to businesses and consumers and the onset of a severe global recession.<ref name="Zandi 2010"/>
There were many causes of the crisis, with commentators assigning different levels of blame to financial institutions, regulators, credit agencies, government housing policies, and consumers, among others.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fcic.law.stanford.edu/report |title=Get the Report: Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission |website=fcic.law.stanford.edu |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> Two [[proximate cause]]s were the rise in subprime lending and the increase in housing speculation. The percentage of lower-quality [[subprime mortgage]]s originated during a given year rose from the historical 8% or lower range to approximately 20% from 2004 to 2006, with much higher ratios in some parts of the U.S.<ref name="ssrn">Michael Simkovic, [http://ssrn.com/abstract=1924831 ''Competition and Crisis in Mortgage Securitization'']</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jchs.harvard.edu/sites/jchs.harvard.edu/files/son2008.pdf |title=Harvard University-The State of the Nation's Housing-2008-|page=4, Figure 4 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> A high percentage of these subprime mortgages, over 90% in 2006 for example, were [[adjustable-rate mortgage]]s.<ref name="Zandi 2010">{{cite book |last=Zandi |first=Mark |year=2010 |title=Financial Shock |publisher=FT Press |isbn=978-0-13-701663-1 |url=https://archive.org/details/financialshockgl00zand }}</ref> Housing speculation also increased, with the share of mortgage originations to investors (i.e. those owning homes other than primary residences) rising significantly from around 20% in 2000 to around 35% in 2006–2007. Investors, even those with prime credit ratings, were much more likely to default than non-investors when prices fell.<ref name="NBER23740"/><ref name="FRBNY2011"/><ref name="Quartz1"/> These changes were part of a broader trend of lowered lending standards and higher-risk mortgage products,<ref name="Zandi 2010"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.vanderbilt.edu/magazines/vanderbilt-magazine/2011/09/missteps-to-mayhem/ |title=Missteps to Mayhem |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> which contributed to U.S. households becoming increasingly indebted. The ratio of household debt to [[disposable personal income]] rose from 77% in 1990 to 127% by the end of 2007.<ref name="The End of the Affair">{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/world/unitedstates/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12637090 |title=The End of the Affair |work=The Economist |date=2008-10-30 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>
When U.S. home prices declined steeply after peaking in mid-2006, it became more difficult for borrowers to refinance their loans. As adjustable-rate mortgages began to reset at higher interest rates (causing higher monthly payments), mortgage delinquencies soared. Securities backed with mortgages, including subprime mortgages, widely held by financial firms globally, lost most of their value. Global investors also drastically reduced purchases of mortgage-backed debt and other securities as part of a decline in the capacity and willingness of the private financial system to support lending.<ref name=ssrn /> Concerns about the soundness of U.S. credit and financial markets led to tightening credit around the world and slowing economic growth in the U.S. and Europe.
The crisis had severe, long-lasting consequences for the U.S. and European economies. The U.S. entered a deep recession, with nearly 9 million jobs lost during 2008 and 2009, roughly 6% of the workforce. The number of jobs did not return to the December 2007 pre-crisis peak until May 2014.<ref name="fred.stlouisfed.org">{{cite journal|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PAYEMS|title=All Employees: Total Nonfarm Payrolls|date=1 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref> U.S. household net worth declined by nearly $13 [[Trillion (short scale)|trillion]] (20%) from its Q2 2007 pre-crisis peak, recovering by Q4 2012.<ref name="https">{{cite journal|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TNWBSHNO|title=Households and Nonprofit Organizations; Net Worth, Level|date=7 June 2018|publisher=}}</ref> U.S. housing prices fell nearly 30% on average and the U.S. stock market fell approximately 50% by early 2009, with stocks regaining their December 2007 level during September 2012.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/SP500|title=S&P 500|date=3 July 2018|publisher=}}</ref> One estimate of lost output and income from the crisis comes to "at least 40% of 2007 [[gross domestic product]]".<ref name=lessons>{{cite journal |last=Johnson |first=Simon |title=Three Unlearned Lessons From the Financial Crisis |journal=Bloomberg |date=Sep 26, 2013 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-09-26/three-unlearned-lessons-from-the-financial-crisis.html |accessdate=17 November 2013}}</ref> Europe also continued to struggle with its own [[European debt crisis|economic crisis]], with elevated unemployment and severe banking impairments estimated at €940 billion between 2008 and 2012.<ref>{{cite paper |ssrn=2294100 |title=Anatomy of a Bail-In |first1=Thomas |last1=Conlon |first2=John |last2=Cotter |date=26 March 2014}}</ref> As of January 2018, U.S. bailout funds had been fully recovered by the government, when interest on loans is taken into consideration. A total of $626B was invested, loaned, or granted due to various bailout measures, while $390B had been returned to the Treasury. The Treasury had earned another $323B in interest on bailout loans, resulting in an $87B profit.<ref name="projects.propublica.org">{{Cite web|url=https://projects.propublica.org/bailout/|title=Bailout Scorecard | Eye on the Bailout | ProPublica|website=projects.propublica.org}}</ref>
==Background and timeline of events== {{Main|Subprime crisis background information|Subprime crisis impact timeline|United States housing bubble|United States housing market correction}} [[File:President Discusses Education, Entrepreneurship & Home Ownership at Indiana Black Expo.jpg|thumb|President George W. Bush discusses Education, Entrepreneurship & Home Ownership at the Indiana Black Expo in 2005]] [[File:Subprime mortgage originations, 1996-2008.GIF|thumb|Subprime mortgage lending jumped dramatically during the 2004–2006 period preceding the crisis (source: [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission Report], p. 70 Figure 5.2).]] [[File:Federal funds rate history and recessions.jpg|thumb|right|Federal funds rate history and recessions]] [[File:Lending & Borrowing Decisions - 10 19 08.png|thumb|Factors contributing to housing bubble]] [[File:Subprime Crisis Diagram - X1.png|thumb|350px|[[Domino effect]] as housing prices declined]]
The immediate cause of the crisis was the bursting of the [[United States housing bubble]] which peaked in approximately 2005–2006.<ref name="Moyers Morgenson">{{cite episode |title=Episode 06292007 |series=[[Bill Moyers Journal]] |network=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] |transcripturl=https://www.pbs.org/moyers/journal/06292007/transcript5.html |transcript=Transcript 29 June 2007 |airdate=2007-06-29}}</ref><ref name="WSJ Housing Bubble Burst">{{cite news |author=Justin Lahart |title=Egg Cracks Differ In Housing, Finance Shells |work=[[WSJ.com]] |publisher=Wall Street Journal |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119845906460548071?mod=googlenews_wsj |date=2007-12-24 |accessdate=2008-07-13}}</ref> An increase in loan incentives such as easy initial terms and a long-term trend of rising housing prices had encouraged borrowers to assume risky mortgages in the anticipation that they would be able to quickly refinance at easier terms. However, once [[interest rate]]s began to rise and housing prices started to drop moderately in 2006–2007 in many parts of the U.S., borrowers were unable to refinance. [[default (finance)|Defaults]] and [[foreclosure]] activity increased dramatically as easy initial terms expired, home prices fell, and [[adjustable-rate mortgage]] (ARM) interest rates reset higher.
As housing prices fell, global investor demand for mortgage-related securities evaporated. This became apparent by July 2007, when investment bank [[Bear Stearns]] announced that two of its hedge funds had imploded. These funds had invested in securities that derived their value from mortgages. When the value of these securities dropped, investors demanded that these hedge funds provide additional collateral. This created a cascade of selling in these securities, which lowered their value further. Economist [[Mark Zandi]] wrote that this 2007 event was "arguably the proximate catalyst" for the financial market disruption that followed.<ref name="Zandi 2010"/>
Several other factors set the stage for the rise and fall of housing prices, and related securities widely held by financial firms. In the years leading up to the crisis, the U.S. received large amounts of foreign money from fast-growing economies in Asia and oil-producing/exporting countries. This inflow of funds combined with low U.S. [[interest rates]] from 2002 to 2004 contributed to easy credit conditions, which fueled both [[economic bubble|housing and credit bubbles]]. Loans of various types (e.g., mortgage, credit card, and auto) were easy to obtain and consumers assumed an unprecedented debt load.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/speech/bernanke20090414a.htm |title=Bernanke-Four Questions About the Financial Crisis |publisher=Federalreserve.gov |date=2009-04-14 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/02/opinion/02krugman.html |title=Opinion – Revenge of the Glut |first=Paul |last=Krugman |date=1 March 2009 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times }}</ref>
As part of the housing and credit booms, the number of financial agreements called [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]] (MBS), which derive their value from mortgage payments and housing prices, greatly increased. Such [[financial innovation]] enabled institutions and investors around the world to invest in the U.S. housing market. As housing prices declined, major global financial institutions that had borrowed and invested heavily in MBS reported significant losses. Defaults and losses on other loan types also increased significantly as the crisis expanded from the housing market to other parts of the economy. Total losses were estimated in the trillions of U.S. dollars globally.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/weo/2009/01/pdf/exesum.pdf |title=IMF Loss Estimates |date= |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref>
While the housing and credit bubbles were growing, a series of factors caused the financial system to become increasingly fragile. [[Federal Reserve|Policymakers]] did not recognize the increasingly important role played by financial institutions such as [[investment banks]] and [[hedge funds]], also known as the [[shadow banking system]]. These entities were not subject to the same regulations as depository banking. Further, shadow banks were able to mask the extent of their risk taking from investors and regulators through the use of complex, off-balance sheet derivatives and securitizations.<ref name="papers.ssrn">{{cite web |author=Michael Simkovic |ssrn=1323190 |title=Secret Liens and the Financial Crisis of 2008 |publisher=American Bankruptcy Law Journal, Vol. 83 |page=253 |year=2009 }}</ref> Economist [[Gary Gorton]] has referred to the 2007–2008 aspects of the crisis as a "[[Bank run|run]]" on the shadow banking system.<ref name="frbatlanta.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.frbatlanta.org/news/CONFEREN/09fmc/gorton.pdf |title=Gary Gorton-NBER and Yale-Slapped in the Face by the Invisible Hand: Banking and the Panic of 2007, Updated May 2009 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>
The complexity of these off-balance sheet arrangements and the securities held, as well as the interconnection between larger financial institutions, made it virtually impossible to re-organize them via bankruptcy, which contributed to the need for government bailouts.<ref name="papers.ssrn" /> Some experts believe these shadow institutions had become as important as commercial (depository) banks in providing credit to the U.S. economy, but they were not subject to the same regulations.<ref name="newyorkfed.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorkfed.org/newsevents/speeches/2008/tfg080609.html |title=Geithner-Speech Reducing Systemic Risk in a Dynamic Financial System |publisher=Newyorkfed.org |date=2008-06-09 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> These institutions as well as certain regulated banks had also assumed significant debt burdens while providing the loans described above and did not have a financial cushion sufficient to absorb large loan defaults or MBS losses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/9c158a92-1a3c-11de-9f91-0000779fd2ac.html |title=Greenspan-We Need a Better Cushion Against Risk |publisher=Ft.com |date=2009-03-26 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref>
The losses experienced by financial institutions on their mortgage-related securities impacted their ability to lend, slowing economic activity. Interbank lending dried-up initially and then loans to non-financial firms were affected. Concerns regarding the stability of key financial institutions drove central banks to take action to provide funds to encourage lending and to restore faith in the [[commercial paper]] markets, which are integral to funding business operations. Governments also [[bailout|bailed out]] key financial institutions, assuming significant additional financial commitments.
The risks to the broader economy created by the housing market downturn and subsequent financial market crisis were primary factors in several decisions by central banks around the world to cut interest rates and governments to implement economic stimulus packages. Effects on global stock markets due to the crisis were dramatic. Between 1 January and 11 October 2008, owners of stocks in U.S. corporations suffered about $8 trillion in losses, as their holdings declined in value from $20 trillion to $12 trillion. Losses in other countries averaged about 40%.<ref>''Wall Street Journal'' Oct. 11, 2008, p. 1</ref>
Losses in the stock markets and housing value declines place further downward pressure on consumer spending, a key economic engine.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/16/opinion/16friedman.html |title=Opinion – Gonna Need a Bigger Boat |first=Thomas L. |last=Friedman |date=16 November 2008 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times }}</ref> Leaders of the larger developed and emerging nations met in November 2008 and March 2009 to formulate strategies for addressing the crisis.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/index.html?Intro=intro3 |title=G-20 Calls for Action on Growth, Overhaul of Financial Rules |publisher=Bloomberg.com |date= |access-date=2009-02-27 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070517104557/http://www.bloomberg.com/index.html?Intro=intro3 |archive-date=2007-05-17 |df=}}</ref> A variety of [[subprime mortgage crisis solutions debate|solutions]] have been proposed by government officials, central bankers, economists, and business executives.<ref name="Stigliz Recommendations">{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/09/17/stiglitz.crisis/index.html |title=Stigliz Recommendations |work=CNN |date=2008-09-17 |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/finance/displayStory.cfm?story_id=12813430 |title=Greenspan-Banks Need More Capital |publisher=Economist.com |date=2008-12-18 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/85106daa-f140-11dd-8790-0000779fd2ac.html?nclick_check=1 |title=FT-Ferguson Beyond the Age of Leverage |publisher=Ft.com |date=2009-02-02 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> In the U.S., the [[Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act]] was signed into law in July 2010 to address some of the causes of the crisis.
==Causes== {{Further|Causes of the 2007–2012 global financial crisis|Causes of the United States housing bubble}}
===Overview=== [[File:FCIC - Housing Bubbles in Multiple Countries 2002-2008.png|thumb|350px|right|Housing price appreciation in selected countries, 2002–2008]] [[File:US Private Debt to GDP by Sector.png|thumb|350px|right|U.S. households and financial businesses significantly increased borrowing (leverage) in the years leading up to the crisis]]
The crisis can be attributed to several factors, which emerged over a number of years. Causes proposed include the inability of homeowners to make their mortgage payments (due primarily to adjustable-rate mortgages resetting, borrowers overextending, [[predatory lending]], and speculation), overbuilding during the boom period, risky mortgage products, increased power of mortgage originators, high personal and corporate debt levels, financial products that distributed and perhaps concealed the risk of mortgage default, monetary and housing policies that encouraged risk-taking and more debt, international [[Balance of trade|trade imbalances]], and inappropriate government regulation.<ref name=ssrn /><ref>{{cite news |first=Joseph |last=Stiglitz |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/09/17/stiglitz.crisis/index.html |title=Time-Stiglitz |publisher=Cnn.com |date=2008-09-17 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Steverman |first=Ben |url=http://www.businessweek.com/investor/content/oct2008/pi20081017_950382.htm?chan=top+news_top+news+index+-+temp_top+story |title=Business Week-The Financial Crisis Blame Game |magazine=Businessweek.com |date=2008-10-18 |access-date=2009-02-27 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417181606/http://www.businessweek.com/investor/content/oct2008/pi20081017_950382.htm?chan=top+news_top+news+index+-+temp_top+story |archive-date=2009-04-17 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Roubini |first=Nouriel |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/story/cms.php?story_id=4591 |title=Roubini – More Doom Ahead |publisher=Foreignpolicy.com |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference |first=M. Jaffee |last=Dwight |title=The Role of GSEs and Housing Policy in the Financial Crisis |date=2010-02-27 |url=http://www.fcic.gov/hearings/pdfs/2010-0227-Jaffee-ppt.pdf |publisher=Fcic.gov |access-date=2012-11-20 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215053834/http://fcic.gov/hearings/pdfs/2010-0227-Jaffee-ppt.pdf |archive-date=2010-12-15 |df=}}</ref> Excessive consumer housing debt was in turn caused by the [[mortgage-backed security]], [[credit default swap]], and [[collateralized debt obligation]] sub-sectors of the [[finance industry]], which were offering irrationally low interest rates and irrationally high levels of approval to [[subprime mortgage]] consumers due in part to faulty financial models.<ref>{{cite news |last=Salmon |first=Felix |title=Recipe for Disaster: The Formula That Killed Wall Street |url=https://www.wired.com/techbiz/it/magazine/17-03/wp_quant?currentPage=all |accessdate=2013-04-03 |newspaper=Wired |date=February 23, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Catherine |last=Donnelly |first2=Paul |last2=Embrechts |title=The devil is in the tails: actuarial mathematics and the subprime mortgage crisis |journal=ASTIN Bulletin |date=January 4, 2010 |volume=40 |issue=1 |pages=1–33 |url=http://www2.ims.nus.edu.sg/preprints/2010-5.pdf |accessdate=2013-04-03|doi=10.2143/AST.40.1.2049222 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Debt consumers were acting in their rational self-interest, because they were unable to audit the finance industry's opaque faulty risk pricing methodology.<ref>{{cite book |first=Tomasz R. |last=Bielecki |first2=Damiano |last2=Brigo |first3=Fédéric |last3=Patras |title=Credit Risk Frontiers: Subprime Crisis, Pricing and Hedging, CVA, MBS, Ratings, and Liquidity |url=https://archive.org/details/creditriskfronti00biel |url-access=limited |year=2011 |publisher=Wiley |pages=[https://archive.org/details/creditriskfronti00biel/page/n450 437]–56 |editor=Tomasz R. Bielecki; Christophette Blanchet-Scalliet |chapter=Chapter 13. Structural Counterparty Risk Valuation for Credit Default Swaps|doi=10.1002/9781118531839.ch13 |isbn=9781118531839 }}</ref>
Among the important catalysts of the subprime crisis were the influx of money from the private sector, the banks entering into the mortgage bond market, government policies aimed at expanding homeownership, speculation by many home buyers, and the predatory lending practices of the mortgage lenders, specifically the adjustable-rate mortgage, [[Subprime lending|2–28 loan]], that mortgage lenders sold directly or indirectly via mortgage brokers.<ref name="The downturn in facts and figures">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7073131.stm |title=The downturn in facts and figures; |publisher=BBC |date=2007-11-21 |accessdate=2009-02-18}}</ref><ref>Ramlall, I., ''The Impact of the Subprime Crisis on Global Financial Markets, Banks and'' ([[Newcastle upon Tyne]]: Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2013), [https://books.google.com/books?id=gS9QBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA5#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 5–31].</ref>{{rp|5–31}} On Wall Street and in the financial industry, [[moral hazard]] lay at the core of many of the causes.<ref name="brown1">{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/news/story/story.aspx?guid={9F4C2252-8BA7-459C-B34E-407DB32921C1}&siteid=rss |last=Brown |first=Bill |title=Uncle Sam as sugar daddy; MarketWatch Commentary: The moral hazard problem must not be ignored |website=MarketWatch |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2008-11-30}}</ref>
In its "Declaration of the Summit on Financial Markets and the World Economy," dated 15 November 2008, leaders of the [[G20 major economies|Group of 20]] cited the following causes:
{{quote|During a period of strong global growth, growing capital flows, and prolonged stability earlier this decade, market participants sought higher yields without an adequate appreciation of the risks and failed to exercise proper due diligence. At the same time, weak underwriting standards, unsound risk management practices, increasingly complex and opaque financial products, and consequent excessive leverage combined to create vulnerabilities in the system. Policy-makers, regulators and supervisors, in some advanced countries, did not adequately appreciate and address the risks building up in financial markets, keep pace with financial innovation, or take into account the systemic ramifications of domestic regulatory actions.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2008/11/20081115-1.html |title=Declaration of G20 |publisher=NARA |date=2008-11-15 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>}}
Federal Reserve Chair [[Ben Bernanke]] testified in September 2010 regarding the causes of the crisis. He wrote that there were shocks or triggers (i.e., particular events that touched off the crisis) and vulnerabilities (i.e., structural weaknesses in the financial system, regulation and supervision) that amplified the shocks. Examples of triggers included: losses on subprime mortgage securities that began in 2007 and a [[bank run|run]] on the [[shadow banking system]] that began in mid-2007, which adversely affected the functioning of money markets. Examples of vulnerabilities in the ''private'' sector included: financial institution dependence on unstable sources of short-term funding such as [[repurchase agreements]] or Repos; deficiencies in corporate risk management; excessive use of leverage (borrowing to invest); and inappropriate usage of derivatives as a tool for taking excessive risks. Examples of vulnerabilities in the ''public'' sector included: statutory gaps and conflicts between regulators; ineffective use of regulatory authority; and ineffective crisis management capabilities. Bernanke also discussed "[[Too big to fail]]" institutions, monetary policy, and trade deficits.<ref name="BernankeFCIC1">{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/testimony/bernanke20100902a.htm |title=Bernanke-Causes of the Recent Financial and Economic Crisis |publisher=Federalreserve.gov |date=2010-09-02 |accessdate=2013-05-31}}</ref>
During May 2010, [[Warren Buffett]] and [[Paul Volcker]] separately described questionable assumptions or judgments underlying the U.S. financial and economic system that contributed to the crisis. These assumptions included: 1) Housing prices would not fall dramatically;<ref name="c-span.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.c-span.org/Watch/Media/2010/06/02/HP/R/33689/Financial+Crisis+Inquiry+Commission.aspx |title=Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission-Warren Buffett Testimony-June 2, 2010 |publisher=C-span.org |date=2010-06-02 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> 2) Free and open financial markets supported by sophisticated financial engineering would most effectively support market efficiency and stability, directing funds to the most profitable and productive uses; 3) Concepts embedded in mathematics and physics could be directly adapted to markets, in the form of various financial models used to evaluate credit risk; 4) Economic imbalances, such as large trade deficits and low savings rates indicative of over-consumption, were sustainable; and 5) Stronger regulation of the [[shadow banking system]] and derivatives markets was not needed.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Paul |last=Volcker |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2010/jun/24/time-we-have-growing-short/ |title=The Time We Have Is Growing Short |journal=The New York Review of Books |date=May 2010 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> Economists surveyed by the University of Chicago during 2017 rated the factors that caused the crisis in order of importance: 1) Flawed financial sector regulation and supervision; 2) Underestimating risks in financial engineering (e.g., CDOs); 3) Mortgage fraud and bad incentives; 4) Short-term funding decisions and corresponding runs in those markets (e.g., repo); and 5) Credit rating agency failures.<ref>[http://www.igmchicago.org/surveys-special/factors-contributing-to-the-2008-global-financial-crisis? IGM Forum-Factors Contributing to 2008 Global Financial Crisis-October 17, 2017]</ref>
The U.S. [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] reported its findings in January 2011. It concluded that "the crisis was avoidable and was caused by: Widespread failures in financial regulation, including the Federal Reserve's failure to stem the tide of toxic mortgages; Dramatic breakdowns in corporate governance including too many financial firms acting recklessly and taking on too much risk; An explosive mix of excessive borrowing and risk by households and Wall Street that put the financial system on a collision course with crisis; Key policy makers ill prepared for the crisis, lacking a full understanding of the financial system they oversaw; and systemic breaches in accountability and ethics at all levels."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fcic.gov/files/news_pdfs/2011-0127-fcic-releases-report.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110130170725/http://www.fcic.gov/files/news_pdfs/2011-0127-fcic-releases-report.pdf|url-status=dead|title=Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission-Press Release-January 27, 2011|archive-date=January 30, 2011}}</ref>
===Narratives=== [[File:U.S. Fixed Investment as Pct GDP.png|thumb|right|350px|U.S. residential and non-residential investment fell relative to GDP during the crisis]] There are several "narratives" attempting to place the causes of the crisis into context, with overlapping elements. Five such narratives include: #There was the equivalent of a [[bank run]] on the [[shadow banking system]], which includes investment banks and other non-depository financial entities. This system had grown to rival the depository system in scale yet was not subject to the same regulatory safeguards.<ref name="frbatlanta.org"/><ref name="KrugmanGeithner1">{{cite journal |url=http://www.nybooks.com/articles/2014/07/10/geithner-does-he-pass-test/ |title=Does He Pass the Test? |journal=The New York Review of Books |first=Paul |last=Krugman |date=10 July 2014 |accessdate=5 October 2017 |via=www.nybooks.com}}</ref> #The economy was being driven by a housing bubble. When it burst, private residential investment (i.e., housing construction) fell by nearly 4% GDP and consumption enabled by bubble-generated housing wealth also slowed. This created a gap in annual demand (GDP) of nearly $1 trillion. Government was unwilling to make up for this private sector shortfall.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/beat-the-press/robert-samuelson-wants-people-to-be-unemployed-the-economics-of-the-economics-of-the-great-recession |title=Robert Samuelson Wants People to Be Unemployed: The Economics of the Economics of the Great Recession |first=Dean |last=Baker |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/07/01/learned-macroeconomic-helplessness/?module=BlogPost-Title&version=Blog+Main&contentCollection=Opinion&action=Click&pgtype=Blogs&region=Body |title=Learned Macroeconomic Helplessness |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017|date=July 2014 }}</ref> #Record levels of [[household debt]] accumulated in the decades preceding the crisis resulted in a [[balance sheet recession]] (similar to [[debt deflation]]) once housing prices began falling in 2006. Consumers began paying down debt, which reduces their consumption, slowing down the economy for an extended period while debt levels are reduced.<ref name="Mian and Sufi2014"/><ref name="KrugmanGeithner1"/> #Housing speculation using high levels of mortgage debt drove many investors with prime-quality mortgages (i.e., those investors in the middle of the credit score distribution) to default and enter foreclosure on investment properties when housing prices fell; the blame on "subprime" homeowners (i.e., those at the bottom of the credit score distribution) was overstated.<ref name="NBER23740"/><ref name="Quartz1">{{cite web |url=https://qz.com/1064061/house-flippers-triggered-the-us-housing-market-crash-not-poor-subprime-borrowers-a-new-study-shows/ |title=House flippers triggered the US housing market crash, not poor subprime borrowers |first=Gwynn |last=Guilford |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref> #Government policies that encouraged home ownership even for those who could not afford it, contributing to lax lending standards, unsustainable housing price increases, and indebtedness.<ref name="Sowell 2009">{{cite book |last=Sowell |first=Thomas |authorlink=Thomas Sowell |year=2009 |title=The Housing Boom and Bust |publisher=Basic Books |pages=57–58 |isbn=978-0-465-01880-2|title-link=The Housing Boom and Bust }}</ref>
Underlying narratives #1-3 is a hypothesis that growing [[Income inequality in the United States|income inequality]] and [[Household income in the United States|wage stagnation]] encouraged families to increase their [[household debt]] to maintain their desired living standard, fueling the bubble. Further, this greater share of income flowing to the top increased the political power of business interests, who used that power to [[Deregulation|deregulate]] or limit regulation of the shadow banking system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.american.edu/cas/economics/pdf/upload/2012-1.pdf |title=Jon Wisman-Wage Stagnation, Rising Inequality and the Crisis of 2008-Retrieved June 2015 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imf.org/external/pubs/ft/wp/2010/wp10268.pdf |title=IMF-Inequality, Leverage and Crises-Kumhoff and Ranciere-November 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.peri.umass.edu/fileadmin/pdf/working_papers/working_papers_251-300/WP282.pdf |title=Stockhammer-Rising Inequality as a Cause of the Present Crisis-Amherst PERI-April 2012 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>
===Housing market=== ====Boom and bust==== {{Main|United States housing bubble|United States housing market correction}} [[File:U.S. Household Debt Relative to Disposable Income and GDP.png|thumb|350px|Household debt relative to disposable income and GDP.]] [[File:Existing Home Sales Chart - Mar 09b.png|thumb|350px|Existing homes sales, inventory, and months supply, by quarter.]] [[File:Subprime crisis - Foreclosures & Bank Instability.png|thumb|350px|Vicious cycles in the housing and financial markets.]]
According to [[Robert J. Shiller]] and other economists, housing price increases beyond the general inflation rate are not sustainable in the long term. From the end of World War II to the beginning of the housing bubble in 1997, housing prices in the US remained relatively stable.<ref>Shiller, R. J., ''Irrational Exuberance: Revised and Expanded Third Edition'' ([[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]] and [[Oxford]]: [[Princeton University Press]], 2015), [https://books.google.com/books?id=_2-YDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA19 19–21].</ref>{{rp|19–21}} The bubble was characterized by higher rates of household debt and lower savings rates, slightly higher rates of home ownership, and of course higher housing prices. It was fueled by low interest rates and large inflows of foreign funds that created easy credit conditions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/24/business/economy/24text-bush.html?_r=2&pagewanted=1&oref=slogin |title=President Bush's Address to Nation |work=The New York Times |date=2008-09-24 |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref>
Between 1997 and 2006 (the peak of the housing bubble), the price of the typical American house increased by 124%.<ref>{{cite news |title=CSI: credit crunch |publisher=Economist.com |url=https://www.economist.com/specialreports/displaystory.cfm?story_id=9972489 |accessdate=19 May 2008 |date=18 October 2007}}</ref> From 1980 to 2001, the ratio of median home prices to median household income (a measure of ability to buy a house) fluctuated from 2.9 to 3.1. In 2004 it rose to 4.0, and by 2006 it hit 4.6.<ref name="businessweek1">{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2008-10-18/the-financial-crisis-blame-gamebusinessweek-business-news-stock-market-and-financial-advice |title=The Financial Crisis Blame Game |work=BusinessWeek |publisher=Businessweek.com |first=Ben |last=Steverman |first2=David |last2=Bogoslaw |date=October 18, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-24}}</ref> The housing bubble was more pronounced in coastal areas where the ability to build new housing was restricted by geography or land use restrictions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/08/08/opinion/that-hissing-sound.html |title=That Hissing Sound |first=Paul |last=Krugman |date=8 August 2005 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017 |newspaper=The New York Times }}</ref> This [[housing bubble]] resulted in quite a few homeowners refinancing their homes at lower interest rates, or financing consumer spending by taking out [[second mortgage]]s secured by the price appreciation. US [[household debt]] as a percentage of annual [[disposable personal income]] was 127% at the end of 2007, versus 77% in 1990.<ref name="The End of the Affair"/><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/13/opinion/13krugman.html NYT-Krugman-Block those Economic Metaphors], December 12, 2010</ref>
While housing prices were increasing, consumers were saving less<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bea.gov/briefrm/saving.htm |title=Bureau of Economic Analysis – Personal Savings Chart |publisher=Bea.gov |date=2009-01-30 |access-date=2009-02-27 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217193831/http://www.bea.gov/briefrm/saving.htm |archive-date=2007-12-17 |url-status=dead |df= }}</ref> and both borrowing and spending more. Household debt grew from $705 billion at year end 1974, 60% of [[disposable personal income]], to $7.4 trillion at yearend 2000, and finally to $14.5 trillion in midyear 2008, 134% of disposable personal income.<ref>[http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/z1/Current/data.htm Z.1 Historical Tables (1974)] and [http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/z1/Current/z1r-5.pdf current Z.1 release (2008)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811102013/http://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/z1/current/z1r-5.pdf |date=2014-08-11 }}, Table B.100, lines 31,48.</ref> During 2008, the typical US household owned 13 credit cards, with 40% of households carrying a balance, up from 6% in 1970.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/id/163449 |title=Zakaria: A More Disciplined America | Newsweek Business | Newsweek.com |publisher=Newsweek.com |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-10-24}}</ref>
Free cash used by consumers from home equity extraction doubled from $627 billion in 2001 to $1,428 billion in 2005 as the housing bubble built, a total of nearly $5 trillion over the period.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/pubs/feds/2007/200720/200720pap.pdf |title=Sources and Uses of Equity Extracted from Homes |year=2007 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://seekingalpha.com/article/33336-home-equity-extraction-the-real-cost-of-free-cash |title=Equity extraction – Charts |publisher=Seekingalpha.com |date=2007-04-25 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSN2330071920070423 |title=Reuters-Spending Boosted by Home Equity Loans |publisher=Reuters.com |date=2007-04-23 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> U.S. home mortgage debt relative to GDP increased from an average of 46% during the 1990s to 73% during 2008, reaching $10.5 trillion.<ref>{{cite news |last=Barr |first=Colin |url=http://money.cnn.com/2009/05/27/news/mortgage.overhang.fortune/index.htm |title=Fortune-The $4 trillion housing headache |publisher=Money.cnn.com |date=2009-05-27 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> From 2001 to 2007, U.S. mortgage debt almost doubled, and the amount of mortgage debt per household rose more than 63%, from $91,500 to $149,500, with essentially stagnant wages.<ref name="FCIC Report-Conclusion-January 2011"/> Economist [[Tyler Cowen]] explained that the economy was highly dependent on this home equity extraction: "In the 1993–1997 period, home owners extracted an amount of equity from their homes equivalent to 2.3% to 3.8% GDP. By 2005, this figure had increased to 11.5% GDP."<ref name="TCowen2011">{{cite book |last=Cowen |first=Tyler |year=2011 |title=The Great Stagnation |publisher=Dutton |isbn=978-0-525-95271-8|title-link=The Great Stagnation }}</ref>
This credit and house price explosion led to a building boom and eventually to a surplus of unsold homes, which caused U.S. housing prices to peak and begin declining in mid-2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.standardandpoors.com/spf/pdf/index/CSHomePrice_Release_123062.pdf |title=Case Shiller Housing Price Index |date=December 2008 |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref> Easy credit, and a belief that house prices would continue to appreciate, had encouraged many subprime borrowers to obtain [[adjustable-rate mortgage]]s. These mortgages enticed borrowers with a below market interest rate for some predetermined period, followed by market interest rates for the remainder of the mortgage's term.
The US home ownership rate increased from 64% in 1994 (about where it had been since 1980) to an all-time high of 69.2% in 2004.<ref>{{cite news |title=CENSUS BUREAU REPORTS ON RESIDENTIAL VACANCIES AND HOMEOWNERSHIP |date=26 October 2007 |publisher=U.S. Census Bureau |url=https://www.census.gov/hhes/www/housing/hvs/qtr307/q307press.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080216030156/http://www.census.gov/hhes/www/housing/hvs/qtr307/q307press.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-date=16 February 2008}}</ref> Subprime lending was a major contributor to this increase in home ownership rates and in the overall demand for housing, which drove prices higher.
Borrowers who would not be able to make the higher payments once the initial grace period ended, were planning to refinance their mortgages after a year or two of appreciation. As a result of the depreciating housing prices, borrowers’ ability to refinance became more difficult. Borrowers who found themselves unable to escape higher monthly payments by refinancing began to default.
As more borrowers stopped making their mortgage payments, foreclosures and the supply of homes for sale increased. This placed downward pressure on housing prices, which further lowered homeowners' [[Negative equity|equity]]. The decline in mortgage payments also reduced the value of [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]], which eroded the net worth and financial health of banks. This [[vicious cycle]] was at the heart of the crisis.<ref>{{cite news |last=Feldstein |first=Martin |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122697004441035727 |title=NYT – How to Help People Whose Homes are Underwater |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=2008-11-18 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>
By September 2008, average U.S. housing prices had declined by over 20% from their mid-2006 peak.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.standardandpoors.com/spf/pdf/index/CSHomePrice_Release_112555.pdf |title=The McGraw-Hill Companies |publisher=Standardandpoors.com |accessdate=2012-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/finance/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12470547 |title=Economist-A Helping Hand to Homeowners |publisher=Economist.com |date=2008-10-23 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> This major and unexpected decline in house prices means that many borrowers have zero or [[negative equity]] in their homes, meaning their homes were worth less than their mortgages. As of March 2008, an estimated 8.8 million borrowers – 10.8% of all homeowners – had negative equity in their homes, a number that is believed to have risen to 12 million by November 2008. By September 2010, 23% of all U.S. homes were worth less than the mortgage loan.<ref name="wellsfargo.com">{{Cite web|url=https://www.wellsfargo.com/downloads/pdf/com/research/economic_commentary/efc09172010.pdf|title=Wells Fargo Economic Research-Weekly Economic and Financial Commentary-September 17, 2010}}</ref>
Borrowers in this situation have an incentive to default on their mortgages as a mortgage is typically [[nonrecourse debt]] secured against the property.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/22/business/22homes.html |title=Negative Equity |work=The New York Times |first1=Edmund L. |last1=Andrews |authorlink1=Edmund Andrews (reporter) |first2=Louis |last2=Uchitelle |authorlink2=Louis Uchitelle |date=2008-02-22 |accessdate=2010-05-24}}</ref> Economist Stan Leibowitz argued in the Wall Street Journal that although only 12% of homes had negative equity, they comprised 47% of foreclosures during the second half of 2008. He concluded that the extent of equity in the home was the key factor in foreclosure, rather than the type of loan, credit worthiness of the borrower, or ability to pay.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124657539489189043 |title=New Evidence on the Foreclosure Crisis |first=Stan |last=Liebowitz |date=4 July 2009 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017 |via=www.wsj.com}}</ref>
Increasing foreclosure rates increases the inventory of houses offered for sale. The number of new homes sold in 2007 was 26.4% less than in the preceding year. By January 2008, the inventory of unsold new homes was 9.8 times the December 2007 sales volume, the highest value of this ratio since 1981.<ref name = "MSNBC-newhome">{{cite web |title=New home sales fell by record amount in 2007 – Real estate – NBC News |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/22880294 |accessdate=2008-05-19 |year=2008}}</ref> Furthermore, nearly four million existing homes were for sale,<ref>{{cite web |title=Housing Meltdown |url=http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/08_06/b4070040767516.htm?chan=rss_topStories_ssi_5 |accessdate=2008-05-19 |year=2008}}</ref> of which roughly 2.2 million were vacant.<ref>{{cite web |first=Rex |last=Nutting |url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/vacancy-rate-owned-homes-rises-record |title=Vacancy rate for owned homes rises to record high 2.9% |date=2009-02-03 |work=MarketWatch.com |accessdate=2012-05-24}}</ref>
This overhang of unsold homes lowered house prices. As prices declined, more homeowners were at risk of default or foreclosure. House prices are expected to continue declining until this inventory of unsold homes (an instance of excess supply) declines to normal levels.<ref>{{cite web |first=Alan |last=Greenspan |url=http://opinionjournal.com/editorial/feature.html?id=110010981 |title=WSJ Greenspan-The Roots of the Mortgage Crisis |publisher=Opinionjournal.com |date=2007-12-12 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> A report in January 2011 stated that U.S. home values dropped by 26 percent from their peak in June 2006 to November 2010, more than the 25.9% drop between 1928 to 1933 when the [[Great Depression]] occurred.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/top-business-stories/decline-in-us-housing-now-greater-than-in-depression/article1865438/ |location=Toronto |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |first=Michael |last=Babad |title=Decline in U.S. housing now greater than in Depression |accessdate=2012-11-20 |date=2012-09-10}}</ref>
From September 2008 to September 2012, there were approximately 4 million completed foreclosures in the U.S. As of September 2012, approximately 1.4 million homes, or 3.3% of all homes with a mortgage, were in some stage of foreclosure compared to 1.5 million, or 3.5%, in September 2011. During September 2012, 57,000 homes completed foreclosure; this is down from 83,000 the prior September but well above the 2000–2006 average of 21,000 completed foreclosures per month.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://multivu.prnewswire.com/mnr/corelogic/56990/ |title=CoreLogic(R) Reports 57,000 Completed Foreclosures in September |website=multivu.prnewswire.com |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>
====Homeowner speculation==== {{Main|Speculation}} Speculative borrowing in residential real estate has been cited as a contributing factor to the subprime mortgage crisis.<ref>{{cite news |title=H. P. Minsky, 77, Economist Who Decoded Lending Trends |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=990CEEDB1F30F935A15753C1A960958260 |first=Louis |last=Uchitelle |newspaper=New York Times |date=October 26, 1996 |accessdate=2008-09-26}}</ref> During 2006, 22% of homes purchased (1.65 million units) were for investment purposes, with an additional 14% (1.07 million units) purchased as vacation homes. During 2005, these figures were 28% and 12%, respectively. In other words, a record level of nearly 40% of homes purchased were not intended as primary residences. David Lereah, [[National Association of Realtors]]'s chief economist at the time, stated that the 2006 decline in investment buying was expected: "Speculators left the market in 2006, which caused investment sales to fall much faster than the primary market."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/04/30/real_estate/speculators_fleeing_housing_markets/index.htm |title=Speculation statistics |work=CNN |date=2007-04-30 |accessdate=2010-05-24 |first=Les |last=Christie}}</ref>
Housing prices nearly doubled between 2000 and 2006, a vastly different trend from the historical appreciation at roughly the rate of inflation. While homes had not traditionally been treated as investments subject to speculation, this behavior changed during the housing boom. Media widely reported condominiums being purchased while under construction, then being "flipped" (sold) for a profit without the seller ever having lived in them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.local10.com/news/4277615/detail.html |title=Speculative flipping |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926235236/http://www.local10.com/news/4277615/detail.html |archive-date=2011-09-26 |df=}}</ref> Some mortgage companies identified risks inherent in this activity as early as 2005, after identifying investors assuming highly leveraged positions in multiple properties.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://realtytimes.com/rtpages/20050321_tighterrules.htm |title=Speculation Risks |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215082440/http://realtytimes.com/rtpages/20050321_tighterrules.htm |archive-date=2012-02-15 |df= }}</ref>
One 2017 NBER study argued that real estate investors (i.e., those owning 2+ homes) were more to blame for the crisis than subprime borrowers: "The rise in mortgage defaults during the crisis was concentrated in the middle of the credit score distribution, and mostly attributable to real estate investors" and that "credit growth between 2001 and 2007 was concentrated in the prime segment, and debt to high-risk [subprime] borrowers was virtually constant for all debt categories during this period." The authors argued that this investor-driven narrative was more accurate than blaming the crisis on lower-income, subprime borrowers.<ref name="NBER23740">{{cite journal |first=Stefania |last=Albanesi |first2=Giacomo |last2=De Giorgi |first3=Jaromir |last3=Nosal |title=Credit Growth and the Financial Crisis: A New Narrative |journal=NBER Working Paper No. 23740 |date=August 2017 |doi=10.3386/w23740 |url=http://www.nber.org/papers/w23740.pdf }}</ref> A 2011 Fed study had a similar finding: "In states that experienced the largest housing booms and busts, at the peak of the market almost half of purchase mortgage originations were associated with investors. In part by apparently misreporting their intentions to occupy the property, investors took on more leverage, contributing to higher rates of default." The Fed study reported that mortgage originations to investors rose from 25% in 2000 to 45% in 2006, for Arizona, California, Florida, and Nevada overall, where housing price increases during the bubble (and declines in the bust) were most pronounced. In these states, investor delinquency rose from around 15% in 2000 to over 35% in 2007 and 2008.<ref name="FRBNY2011">{{cite web |url=https://www.newyorkfed.org/medialibrary/media/research/staff_reports/sr514.pdf |title=FRBNY-Haughwout, Lee, Tracy, and Klaauw-Real Estate Investors, the Leverage Cycle, and the Housing Market Crisis-September 2011-See page 18 and Figures 3 and 11 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017}}</ref>
Nicole Gelinas of the [[Manhattan Institute]] described the negative consequences of not adjusting tax and mortgage policies to the shifting treatment of a home from conservative inflation hedge to speculative investment.<ref>{{cite web |first=Nicole |last=Gelinas |url=http://www.city-journal.org/2008/eon1029ng.html |title=Sheltering Speculation |work=City Journal 29 October 2008 |publisher=City-journal.org |date=2008-10-29 |accessdate=2012-11-20}}</ref> Economist [[Robert Shiller]] argued that speculative bubbles are fueled by "contagious optimism, seemingly impervious to facts, that often takes hold when prices are rising. Bubbles are primarily social phenomena; until we understand and address the psychology that fuels them, they're going to keep forming."<ref>{{cite web |last=Crook |first=Clive |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200807/housing |title=Shiller-Infectious Exuberance-The Atlantic |publisher=Theatlantic.com |date=July 2008 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref> Keynesian economist [[Hyman Minsky]] described how speculative borrowing contributed to rising debt and an eventual collapse of asset values.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://mises.org/story/2787 |title=Does the Current Financial Crisis Vindicate the Economics of Hyman Minsky? – Frank Shostak – Mises Institute |publisher=Mises.org |date= |accessdate=2008-10-19}}</ref>
[[Warren Buffett]] testified to the [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]]: "There was the greatest bubble I've ever seen in my life...The entire American public eventually was caught up in a belief that housing prices could not fall dramatically."<ref name="c-span.org"/>
====High-risk mortgage loans and lending/borrowing practices==== [[File:Subprime Mortgage Offer.jpeg|thumb|300px|A mortgage brokerage in the US advertising subprime mortgages in July 2008.]] In the years before the crisis, the behavior of lenders changed dramatically. Lenders offered more and more loans to higher-risk borrowers,<ref name=ssrn /><ref>{{cite news |title=Minorities hit hard by rising costs of subprime loans |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/economy/housing/2007-04-25-subprime-minorities-usat_N.htm |accessdate=2008-05-19 |date=April 25, 2007 |work=USA Today |first1=Sue |last1=Kirchhoff |first2=Judy |last2=Keen}}</ref> including [[Illegal immigration to the United States|undocumented immigrant]]s.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/08/08/news/economy/illegal_immigrants/ |title=Banks help undocumented workers own their own home – Aug. 8, 2005 |publisher=Money.cnn.com |date=August 8, 2005 |accessdate=2008-10-24 |first1=Shaheen |last1=Pasha}}</ref> Lending standards deteriorated particularly between 2004 and 2007, as the [[government-sponsored enterprise]] (GSE) mortgage market share (i.e. the share of [[Fannie Mae]] and [[Freddie Mac]], which specialized in [[Mortgage loan#Standard or conforming mortgages|conventional, conforming]], non-subprime mortgages) declined and private securitizers share grew, rising to more than half of mortgage securitizations.<ref name=ssrn />
[[File:Mortgage delinquencies by loan type - 1998-2010.GIF|thumb|350px| Historically less than 2% of homebuyers lost their homes to foreclosure. But by 2009 over 40% of subprime adjustable rate mortgages were past due. (source: [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Report], p.217, figure 11.2)]] Subprime mortgages grew from 5% of total originations ($35 billion) in 1994,<ref name = "bankrate-20040515a2">{{cite web |title=Warning signs of a bad home loan (Page 2 of 2) |url=http://www.bankrate.com/brm/news/mortgages/20040615a2.asp |accessdate=2008-05-19 |date=June 15, 2004}}</ref><ref name = "bankrate-20040515a2"/><ref name = "NPR-Brace">{{cite web |title=NPR: Economists Brace for Worsening Subprime Crisis (9% in 1996) |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=12561184 |accessdate=2008-05-19 |date=June 15, 2004}}</ref> to 20% ($600 billion) in 2006.<ref name = "NPR-Brace"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/speech/bernanke20080314a.htm |title=FRB: Speech-Bernanke, Fostering Sustainable Homeownership |publisher=Federalreserve.gov |date=March 14, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0DE7DB153EF933A0575AC0A96F958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all |title=Fannie Mae Eases Credit To Aid Mortgage Lending |newspaper=New York Times |date=1999-09-30 |first=Steven A. |last=Holmes}}</ref> Another indicator of a "classic" boom-bust [[credit cycle]], was a closing in the difference between subprime and prime mortgage interest rates (the "subprime markup") between 2001 and 2007.<ref name="ssrn.com-1020396"> {{cite journal|title=Understanding the Subprime Mortgage Crisis|last=Demyanyk|first=Yuliya|last2=Van Hemert|first2=Otto|date=2008-08-19|journal=Working Paper Series|publisher=[[SSRN|Social Science Electronic Publishing]]|ssrn=1020396|doi = 10.2139/ssrn.1020396}}</ref>
In addition to considering higher-risk borrowers, lenders had offered progressively riskier loan options and borrowing incentives. In 2005, the median [[down payment]] for first-time home buyers was 2%, with 43% of those buyers making no down payment whatsoever.<ref>{{cite news |last=Knox |first=Noelle |title=43% of first-time home buyers put no money down |newspaper=[[USA Today]] |date=2006-01-17 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/perfi/housing/2006-01-17-real-estate-usat_x.htm |accessdate=2008-10-18}}</ref> By comparison, China has down payment requirements that exceed 20%, with higher amounts for non-primary residences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sgpropertypress.wordpress.com/2007/09/19/china-to-raise-downpayment-for-second-homes-sources/ |title=China Down Payment Requirements |publisher=Sgpropertypress.wordpress.com |date=2007-09-19 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>
[[File:Mortgage loan fraud.svg|thumb|350px|Growth in mortgage loan fraud based upon US Department of the Treasury Suspicious Activity Report Analysis]] To produce more mortgages and more securities, mortgage qualification guidelines became progressively looser. First, "stated income, verified assets" (SIVA) loans replaced proof of income with a "statement" of it. Then, "no income, verified assets" (NIVA) loans eliminated proof of employment requirements. Borrowers needed only to show proof of money in their bank accounts. "No Income, No Assets" (NINA) or [[Ninja loans]] eliminated the need to prove, or even to state any owned assets. All that was required for a mortgage was a credit score.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stock-market-investors.com/stock-investment-risk/the-subprime-mortgage-crisis-explained.html |title=The Subprime Mortgage Crisis Explained |publisher=Stock-market-investors.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-03}}</ref>
Types of mortgages became more risky as well. The interest-only adjustable-rate mortgage (ARM), allowed the homeowner to pay only the interest (not principal) of the mortgage during an initial "teaser" period. Even looser was the "payment option" loan, in which the homeowner has the option to make monthly payment that do not even cover the interest for the first two or three year initial period of the loan. Nearly one in 10 mortgage borrowers in 2005 and 2006 took out these "option ARM" loans,<ref name="FCIC Report-Conclusion-January 2011"/> and an estimated one-third of ARMs originated between 2004 and 2006 had "teaser" rates below 4%. After the initial period, monthly payments might double<ref name="NPR-Brace"/> or even triple.<ref name=FDIC>{{cite web |title=Interest-only mortgage payments and Option Payment ARMs |url=http://www.fdic.gov/consumers/consumer/interest-only/ |work=10/31/2006 |publisher=FDIC |accessdate=8 September 2013}}</ref>
The proportion of subprime ARM loans made to people with credit scores high enough to qualify for conventional mortgages with better terms increased from 41% in 2000 to 61% by 2006. In addition, mortgage brokers in some cases received incentives from lenders to offer subprime ARM's even to those with credit ratings that merited a conforming (i.e., non-subprime) loan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.realestatejournal.com/buysell/mortgages/20071204-simon.html |title=WSJ – Subprime Debacle Traps Even Credit Worthy |publisher=Realestatejournal.com |date=2007-12-04 |accessdate=2009-02-27}}</ref>
[[Mortgage underwriting]] standards declined precipitously during the boom period. The use of automated loan approvals allowed loans to be made without appropriate review and documentation.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bank Systems & Technology |url=http://www.banktech.com/story/featured/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=21401117 |access-date=2008-05-19 |year=2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717022033/http://www.banktech.com/business-intelligence/21401117 |archive-date=2012-07-17 |url-status=dead |df= }}</ref> In 2007, 40% of all subprime loans resulted from automated underwriting.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lynnley |last=Browning |title=The Subprime Loan Machine |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/23/business/23speed.html?_r=1&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&oref=slogin |work=nytimes.com |date=2007-03-27 |accessdate=2008-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=REALTOR Magazine-Daily News-Are Computers to Blame for Bad Lending? |url=http://www.realtor.org/rmodaily.nsf/f3c66d0c6457c1e1862570af000cb13b/b187c47b7d488dd8862572a7004ec179?OpenDocument |accessdate=2008-05-19 |year=2008}}</ref> The chairman of the Mortgage Bankers Association claimed that mortgage brokers, while profiting from the home loan boom, did not do enough to examine whether borrowers could repay.<ref>{{cite web |title=Brokers, bankers play subprime blame game – Real estate |website=NBC News |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/18804054 |accessdate=2008-05-19 |year=2008}}</ref> [[Mortgage fraud]] by lenders and borrowers increased enormously.<ref>{{cite news |first=Tyler |last=Cowen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/13/business/13view.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=Tyler+Cowen&oref=login&oref=slogin |title=So We Thought. But Then Again . . |publisher=Nytimes.com |newspaper=New York Times |date=January 13, 2008 |accessdate=2008-10-26}}</ref>
The [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] reported in January 2011 that many mortgage lenders took eager borrowers' qualifications on faith, often with a "willful disregard" for a borrower's ability to pay. Nearly 25% of all mortgages made in the first half of 2005 were "interest-only" loans. During the same year, 68% of "option ARM" loans originated by [[Countrywide Financial]] and [[Washington Mutual]] had low- or no-documentation requirements.<ref name="FCIC Report-Conclusion-January 2011">{{Citation |work=[[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] |title=The Financial Crisis Inquiry Report: Final Report of the National Commission on the Causes of the Financial and Economic Crisis in the United States |publisher=[[United States Government Publishing Office|Government Printing Office]] | location = [[Washington, D. C.]] |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/content-detail.html |accessdate=2012-06-04 |date=2011-01-25}}</ref>
At least one study has suggested that the decline in standards was driven by a shift of mortgage securitization from a tightly controlled duopoly to a competitive market in which mortgage originators held the most sway.<ref name=ssrn /> The worst mortgage vintage years coincided with the periods during which Government Sponsored Enterprises (specifically Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac) were at their weakest, and mortgage originators and private label securitizers were at their strongest.<ref name=ssrn />
Why was there a market for these low quality private label securitizations? In a [[Peabody Award]] winning program, [[National Public Radio|NPR]] correspondents argued that a "Giant Pool of Money" (represented by $70 trillion in worldwide fixed income investments) sought higher yields than those offered by U.S. Treasury bonds early in the decade. Further, this pool of money had roughly doubled in size from 2000 to 2007, yet the supply of relatively safe, income generating investments had not grown as fast. Investment banks on Wall Street answered this demand with [[financial innovation]] such as the [[mortgage-backed security]] (MBS) and [[collateralized debt obligation]] (CDO), which were assigned safe ratings by the credit rating agencies.
In effect, Wall Street connected this pool of money to the mortgage market in the U.S., with enormous fees accruing to those throughout the mortgage supply chain, from the mortgage broker selling the loans, to small banks that funded the brokers, to the giant investment banks behind them. By approximately 2003, the supply of mortgages originated at traditional lending standards had been exhausted. However, continued strong demand for MBS and CDO began to drive down lending standards, as long as mortgages could still be sold along the supply chain. Eventually, this speculative bubble proved unsustainable. NPR described it this way:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pri.org/business/giant-pool-of-money.html |title="This American Life": Giant Pool of Money wins Peabody |publisher=Pri.Org |date= |access-date=2012-11-20 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100415153017/http://www.pri.org/business/giant-pool-of-money.html |archive-date=2010-04-15 |df=}}</ref>
{{quote|The problem was that even though housing prices were going through the roof, people weren't making any more money. From 2000 to 2007, the median household income stayed flat. And so the more prices rose, the more tenuous the whole thing became. No matter how lax lending standards got, no matter how many exotic mortgage products were created to shoehorn people into homes they couldn't possibly afford, no matter what the mortgage machine tried, the people just couldn't swing it. By late 2006, the average home cost nearly four times what the average family made. Historically it was between two and three times. And mortgage lenders noticed something that they'd almost never seen before. People would close on a house, sign all the mortgage papers, and then default on their very first payment. No loss of a job, no medical emergency, they were underwater before they even started. And although no one could really hear it, that was probably the moment when one of the biggest speculative bubbles in American history popped.}}

===Financial markets=== ====Boom and collapse of the shadow banking system==== [[File:Shadow banking.GIF|thumb|350px|Comparison of the growth of traditional banking and shadow banking<ref>''[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission Report]'', figure 2.1, p. 32</ref>]] The [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] reported in January 2011: <blockquote>"In the early part of the 20th century, we erected a series of protections – the Federal Reserve as a [[lender of last resort]], federal deposit insurance, ample regulations – to provide a bulwark against the panics that had regularly plagued America's banking system in the 19th century. Yet, over the past 30-plus years, we permitted the growth of a shadow banking system – opaque and laden with short term debt – that rivaled the size of the traditional banking system. Key components of the market – for example, the multitrillion-dollar repo lending market, off-balance-sheet entities, and the use of over-the-counter derivatives – were hidden from view, without the protections we had constructed to prevent financial meltdowns. We had a 21st-century financial system with 19th-century safeguards."<ref name="FCIC Report-Conclusion-January 2011"/></blockquote>
In a June 2008 speech, President of the NY Federal Reserve Bank [[Timothy Geithner]], who later became Secretary of the Treasury, placed significant blame for the freezing of credit markets on a "run" on the entities in the "parallel" banking system, also called the [[shadow banking system]]. These entities became critical to the credit markets underpinning the financial system, but were not subject to the same regulatory controls as depository banks. Further, these entities were vulnerable because they borrowed short-term in liquid markets to purchase long-term, illiquid and risky assets. This meant that disruptions in credit markets would make them subject to rapid [[leverage (finance)|deleveraging]], selling their long-term assets at depressed prices.<ref name="newyorkfed.org"/>
Repo and other forms of shadow banking accounted for an estimated 60% of the "overall US banking system," according to Nobel laureate economist [[Paul Krugman]].<ref name=slump/> Geithner described its "entities": <blockquote>"In early 2007, [[asset-backed commercial paper]] conduits, in structured investment vehicles, in auction-rate preferred securities, tender option bonds and variable rate demand notes, had a combined asset size of roughly $2.2 trillion. Assets financed overnight in triparty repo grew to $2.5 trillion. Assets held in hedge funds grew to roughly $1.8 trillion. The combined balance sheets of the then five major investment banks totaled $4 trillion. In comparison, the total assets of the top five bank holding companies in the United States at that point were just over $6 trillion, and total assets of the entire banking system were about $10 trillion."</blockquote> He stated that the "combined effect of these factors was a financial system vulnerable to self-reinforcing asset price and credit cycles."<ref name="newyorkfed.org"/>
Krugman described the run on the shadow banking system as the "core of what happened" to cause the crisis. <blockquote>As the shadow banking system expanded to rival or even surpass conventional banking in importance, politicians and government officials should have realized that they were re-creating the kind of financial vulnerability that made the Great Depression possible – and they should have responded by extending regulations and the financial safety net to cover these new institutions. Influential figures should have proclaimed a simple rule: anything that does what a bank does, anything that has to be rescued in crises the way banks are, should be regulated like a bank.</blockquote> He referred to this lack of controls as "malign neglect."<ref name="Krugman 2009">{{cite book |last=Krugman |first=Paul |authorlink=Paul Krugman |year=2009 |title=The Return of Depression Economics and the Crisis of 2008 |publisher=W.W. Norton Company Limited |isbn=978-0-393-07101-6|title-link=The Return of Depression Economics and the Crisis of 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/02/opinion/02krugman.html |title=Opinion - Financial Reform 101 |first=Paul |last=Krugman |date=1 April 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=5 October 2017 |via=www.nytimes.com}}</ref>
The securitization markets supported by the shadow banking system started to close down in the spring of 2007 and nearly shut-down in the fall of 2008. More than a third of the private credit markets thus became unavailable as a source of funds.<ref name="Search Site"/> According to the [[Brookings Institution]], the traditional banking system does not have the capital to close this gap as of June 2009: "It would take a number of years of strong profits to generate sufficient capital to support that additional lending volume." The authors also indicate that some forms of securitization are "likely to vanish forever, having been an artifact of excessively loose credit conditions."<ref name="brookings.edu"/>
Economist [[Gary Gorton]] wrote in May 2009: <blockquote>Unlike the historical banking panics of the 19th and early 20th centuries, the current banking panic is a wholesale panic, not a retail panic. In the earlier episodes, depositors ran to their banks and demanded cash in exchange for their checking accounts. Unable to meet those demands, the banking system became insolvent. The current panic involved financial firms "running" on other financial firms by not renewing sale and repurchase agreements (repo) or increasing the repo margin ("haircut"), forcing massive [[deleveraging]], and resulting in the banking system being insolvent.<ref name="frbatlanta.org"/></blockquote>

====Securitization==== [[File:Borrowing Under a Securitization Structure.png|thumb|350px|Borrowing under a securitization structure.]] [[File:CDO - FCIC and IMF Diagram.png|thumb|350px|IMF diagram of CDO and RMBS.]] {{Further|Securitization|Mortgage-backed security}} [[Securitization]] – the bundling of bank loans to create [[Trade (financial instrument)|tradeable]] [[Bond (finance)|bond]]s – started in the mortgage industry in the 1970s, when Government Sponsored Enterprises (GSEs) began to pool relatively safe, conventional, "[[Conforming loan|conforming]]" or "prime" mortgages, create "[[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]]" (MBS) from the pool, sell them to investors, guaranteeing these securities/bonds against default on the underlying mortgages.<ref name=ssrn /><ref>{{cite book |page=[https://archive.org/details/fixedincomesecur00tuck_102/page/n579 568] |title=Fixed Income Securities: Tools for Today's Markets |url=https://archive.org/details/fixedincomesecur00tuck_102 |url-access=limited |last=Tuckman |first=Bruce |last2=Serrat |first2=Angel |publisher=Wiley |year=2011}}</ref> This "originate-to-distribute" model had advantages over the old "originate-to-hold" model,<ref name=FCIR-p89>{{cite book |title=Financial Crisis Inquiry Report |year=2010 |publisher=GPO |page=89 |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/GPO-FCIC/pdf/GPO-FCIC.pdf}}</ref> where a bank originated a loan to the borrower/homeowner and retained the credit (default) risk. Securitization removed the loans from a bank's books, enabling the bank to remain in compliance with capital requirement laws. More loans could be made with proceeds of the MBS sale. The [[Market liquidity|liquidity]] of a national and even international mortgage market allowed capital to flow where mortgages were in demand and funding short. However, securitization created a [[moral hazard]] – the bank/institution making the loan no longer had to worry if the mortgage was paid off<ref name="Devils-19">{{cite book |first=Bethany |last=McLean |first2=Joe |last2=Nocera |title=All the Devils Are Here |url=https://archive.org/details/alldevilsarehere00mcle |url-access=registration |year=2010 |publisher=Portfolio, Penguin |page=[https://archive.org/details/alldevilsarehere00mcle/page/19 19] |quote=After the REMIC battle, [whatever that was] Wall Street realized it was never going to dislodge Fannie and Freddie from their dominant position as the securitizers of traditional mortgages. ... 'Their effort became one to find products they could profit from where they didn't have to compete with Fannie.'}}</ref> – giving them incentive to process mortgage transactions but not to ensure their credit quality.<ref>{{cite news |title='Moral hazard' helps shape mortgage mess |first=Holden |last=Lewis |publisher=Bankrate.com |url=http://www.bankrate.com/brm/news/mortgages/20070418_subprime_mortgage_morality_a1.asp?caret=3c |date=18 April 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Amiyatosh K. |last=Purnanandam |title=Originate-to-distribute Model and the Subprime Mortgage Crisis |journal=Review of Financial Studies |volume=24 |issue=6 |year=2011 |pages=1881–1915 |doi=10.1093/rfs/hhq106 }}</ref> Bankers were no longer around to work out borrower problems and minimize defaults during the course of the mortgage.<ref name="autogenerated1">Lemke, Lins and Picard, ''Mortgage-Backed Securities'', Chapter 3 (Thomson West, 2013 ed.).</ref>
With the high [[down payment]]s and [[Credit score in the United States|credit score]]s of the conforming mortgages used by GSE, this danger was minimal.<ref name=samuelson>{{cite web |last=Samuelson |first=Robert J. |title=Reckless Optimism |url=http://www.claremont.org/publications/crb/id.1916/article_detail.asp |date=January 31, 2012 |publisher=Claremont Institute |access-date=30 September 2013 |quote=Most home mortgages were relatively safe investments, and Fannie and Freddie's lending standards were conservative. By regulation, the GSEs were not allowed to deal in mortgages above a given amount ($417,000 in 2007, before the crisis). Private lenders, therefore, were left with both the larger and the riskier mortgages, all of which were called "non-conforming" loans because they didn't fit the GSEs' criteria. What these "private label" or "non-agency" originators did do was to use "[[structured finance]]" to create securities. ====Financial institution debt levels and incentives==== [[File:Leverage ratios for major investment banks.svg|thumb|350px|Leverage ratios of investment banks increased significantly between 2003 and 2007.]]
The [[Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission]] reported in January 2011 that: "From 1978 to 2007, the amount of debt held by the financial sector soared from $3 trillion to $36 trillion, more than doubling as a share of gross domestic product. The very nature of many Wall Street firms changed – from relatively staid private partnerships to publicly traded corporations taking greater and more diverse kinds of risks. By 2005, the 10 largest U.S. commercial banks held 55% of the industry's assets, more than double the level held in 1990. On the eve of the crisis in 2006, financial sector profits constituted 27% of all corporate profits in the United States, up from 15% in 1980."<ref name="FCIC Report-Conclusion-January 2011"/>
Many [[financial institutions]], [[investment bank]]s in particular, issued large amounts of debt during 2004–07, and invested the proceeds in [[Mortgage-backed security|mortgage-backed securities]] (MBS), essentially betting that house prices would continue to rise, and that households would continue to make their mortgage payments. Borrowing at a lower interest rate and investing the proceeds at a higher interest rate is a form of [[financial leverage]]. This is analogous to an individual taking out a second mortgage on his residence to invest in the stock market. This strategy proved profitable during the housing boom, but resulted in large losses when house prices began to decline and mortgages began to default. Beginning in 2007, financial institutions and individual investors holding MBS also suffered significant losses from mortgage payment defaults and the resulting decline in the value of MBS.<ref name="BlackburnSMC1">{{Cite journal |last=Blackburn |first=Robin | author-link = Robin Blackburn |title=The Subprime Crisis |journal=[[New Left Review]] |volume=II |issue=50 |date=March–April 2008 |url=http://newleftreview.org/II/50/robin-blackburn-the-subprime-crisis |ref=harv }}</ref>
A 2004 [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) decision related to the [[net capital rule]] allowed US investment banks to issue substantially more debt, which was then used to purchase MBS. Over 2004–07, the top five US investment banks each significantly increased their financial leverage (see diagram), which increased their vulnerability to the declining value of MBSs. These five institutions reported over $4.1 trillion in debt for fiscal year 2007, about 30% of US nominal GDP for 2007.
